Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Investigation of Galvanic Reaction Barriers in High Temperature High Voltage Conductors

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This GOALI project will examine the combined effect of mechanical, electrical and environmental fields on the structural integrity of glass/polymer composite sheaths as barriers against galvanic reactions in the next generation high voltage polymer based composite conductors. Through this project, our understanding of the combined effects of ozone, pollution, high temperature, mechanical and electrical loads, and acids/moisture on the composites will be significantly improved leading to major advances in high voltage engineering. This research will have very strong interdisciplinary experimental and numerical components. The composites will be subjected to a variety of extreme high voltage/temperature in-service stresses and their failure characteristics will be determined. Various types of transport mechanisms in the composites will be numerically simulated though multiscale modeling to understand the galvanic reaction processes in the composites and the conductors. We will optimize the design of the composites using nanotechnology maximizing their effectiveness as galvanic reaction barriers for future designs of the conductors. The project will be done in very close collaborations with several US utilities and manufactures.
Due to the rapidly increasing demand for electric power and the development of new sources of energy, there is an urgent need in this country to be able to transport more electric power, more efficiently, using the existing rights-of-way. However, the current designs of high voltage conductors based on steel (for strength) and aluminum (for conduction) strands used in regional grids exhibit several limitations. Therefore, new conductors, with significantly better resistance to in-service conditions are being designed. One of them is the Polymer Core Composite Conductor (PCCC). PCCCs are based on a unidirectional polymer matrix composite core with carbon and glass fibers for strength and stiffness, and aluminum strands for conduction. They can transport three times more power than the current designs based on steel and aluminum. And these conductors will be studied in this research in order to improve their design or to replace them with entirely new designs. The project will enhance the reputation of American high voltage manufacturing around the world and will also improve the level of confidence among the potential users of PCC conductors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background Information: Due to the rapidly increasing demand for electric power and the development of new sources of energy, there is an urgent need in this country to be able to transport more electric power, more efficiently, using the existing rights-of-way. However, the current designs of High Voltage (HV) conductors based on steel (for strength) and aluminum (for conduction) strands  used in regional grids exhibit several limitations. Primarily, they are limited by their propensity to sag. Therefore, new HV conductors, with significantly better resistance to sagging are being designed One of them is the Polymer Core Composite Conductor (PCCC).  PCCCs are based on a unidirectional polymer matrix composite core with carbon and glass fibers for strength and stiffness, and aluminum strands for conduction. They can transport three times more power than the current designs based on steel and aluminum. In addition, the PCC conductors sag less than established overhead conductors. Since the conductors are designed with an expected life of 50 years, their structural deterioration with time needs to be well understood considering the in-service temperatures of up to 200°C, high concentrations of ozone, nitric acid and other pollutants, as well as, a variety of multi-axial static and dynamic mechanical loading conditions and very high electric fields. 

General Research Accomplishments: We have examined the effect of ozone, moisture and temperature on the structural integrity of glass/high temperature epoxy sheaths as barriers against galvanic reactions in PCCCs. Our research had very strong experimental and numerical components. The glass reinforced polymer (GRP) and carbon fiber/polymer composites presently used in PCCCs were subjected to a variety of mechanical, electrical and environmental stresses and their failure characteristics were determined. We have optimized the design of the composites maximizing their effectiveness as galvanic reaction barriers for future designs of PCC conductors. Several transport mechanisms through the composites and other HV transmission materials were numerically simulated to better understand the galvanic reaction processes and other aging mechanisms in PCCC composites. This research was done initially in very close collaborations with three major US utilities and one manufacturer of the PCCC, namely, the Bonneville Power Administration, the Western Area Power Administration, the Tri-State Generation and Transmission Association, Inc., and the Composite Technology Corporation Global.

Intellectual Merit: The combined synergistic effects of mechanical, electrical and environmental fields on polymer matrix composites with either glass or carbon fibers used in high voltage transmission had not been widely investigated in the past. Since these composites are becoming standard materials in HV engineering, there was an urgent need to perform more interdisciplinary research in this area in order to improve our understanding of the effect of these fields on the long term performance of PCC conductors. Through this project, our understanding of the effects of ozone, high temperature, mechanical and electrical loads, and acids/moisture on PCCC composites has been be significantly improved leading to major advances in HV materials engineering. 

Broader Impacts: In general, this project improved our understanding of the effects of HV fields on the structural integrity of various HV transmission structures based on polymers and their composites. It created an exceptional educational environment for nine graduate PhD and MS students and eight undergraduate students working on two senior design projects. The projected resulted in 18 journal publications, all in major international journals with large impact factors, several conference papers, 3 completed PhD theses, 5 completed MS dissertations, and 5 significantly advanced additional PhD projects.

The Goali project greatly strengthened the initial research collaborations between the DU researchers and their initial industry partners (BPA, WAPA, Tri-State and CTC Global). As a result of the strong interactions between the researchers of the Goali project and their industrial partners, the National Science Foundation awarded a much larger grant to this group through their I/UCRC program in March 2014. The University of Denver was asked to build jointly with three other groups from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the Michigan Technological University, and the University of Connecticut  the Center for Novel High Voltage/Temperature Materials and Structures. Since 2014, the Center has been supported by 20 mostly large electrical and aerospace industries with about 35 participating graduate students and 12 faculty members. In 2017, after three years of operation the HVT Center was highly ranked by NSF and its participating industries.

Major Impact on the US Economy: This project has enhanced the reputation of American HV materials manufacturing around the world and improved the level of confidence among the potential users of PCC conductors. Since the project was very strongly related to infrastructure, energy transport and the efficiency of the national electric grid, its long-term economic benefits should be very significant.
